metadata.title: FOSSDA: Exploring the Impact of the ASF with Daniel Ruggeri
metadata.description: In this series of interviews focusing on the Apache Software Foundation, ASF Member Daniel Ruggeri shares his journey to open source, which started with the ASF as a contributor to the httpd project. Today, Daniel imparts his open source wisdom at the university level (https://github.com/DRuggeri/OSSClass), and shares some of his experiences with us in this conversation.

blocks.text: So welcome again to another edition of the FOSSDA series of interviews around the history of open source. This particular series is focused on the history around the Apache Software Foundation. And my name is Brian Proffitt, VP of Marketing and Publicity with Apache. And I'm very pleased to have today as our guest, Daniel Ruggeri, who is a member of the ASF and also a member of the HTTP project management committee, yes.
So welcome, Daniel. Thanks for coming in.
Yeah, thank you, Brian. Happy to be here.

So really, the focus of this conversation is really going to be about you and your journey into open source. So to kick it off, can you like share a little bit about yourself and how you kind of started in with your journey in open source and the ASF?
Yeah, absolutely.

So my history with open source kind of coincided with my kicking off in my professional career. I was an internet operations web administrator back in 2006, which is a fancy way of saying I was the guy that would wake up at three in the morning when a website went down. So being very, very heavy into Apache HTTP as a technology. We used the heck out of that system or out of the software. And over time, you know, I'd kind of hang out on the dev list, ask a couple of questions, realized, hey, it would be really great if the software behaved a little bit differently. And I did this almost unthinkable thing.

I submitted a patch and they accepted the patch and it made its way into the release. And that was like the gateway drug that got me into more and more involvement with the Apache Software Foundation. So it really started out as, hey, I'm using this thing and I can see its source code. Oh, I can propose changing the source code. And it just kind of grew from there.

That's interesting. I think you're the first person we've talked to that described it as a gateway drug. So maybe not that particular metaphor, but why did you keep going? I mean, did the capability of being able to contribute like that hook you in?

Yeah, I think that's the best way to describe it, actually. And I think gateway drug is a little bit of an off color, but apropos analogy, because that's one of the things that I particularly like about the Apache Software Foundation is this strong, very firm belief in open governance. Obviously I've engaged in a lot of different open source projects throughout my career, and I tend to find that the best results happen when the governance happens in plain sight, when everybody who has a vested interest can participate. That sort of open governance model is something that is very near and dear to my heart and that openness of how projects should live and the framework. Because I've seen a number of projects that are like the lone wolf contributor model where it's just one guy or projects that are, it's really entirely dominated by one company, one organization, and they really set the direction.

It doesn't matter if you want to show up and contribute and enhance. If it's not on their roadmap, they don't care. Or even other scenarios where it's just not a sustainable open source ecosystem and one person or one company calls it quits and then now that project is dead. That's a potentially dangerous thing if you're basing professional life off of that project. But obviously, something that you want to invest in from a time and volunteerism perspective, you kind of want something that's going to be around longer too.

Yeah, well, and sustainability is often one of the reasons why open source projects are scrutinized because people don't necessarily believe that such a thing could actually keep going. And again, yeah, you're right. The ASF sort of lends to that very strongly.
You mentioned you've been involved in other projects. Are there things about working in open source in general that appeal to you, whether you're in the ASF or not?
Hey, Brian, I'm sorry. I think I may have had a connectivity problem.
Could you repeat that first part of the question?
Sure.

So I was asking, since you said you've been involved in other projects outside of the ASF, are there things that would interest you about open source that you like that are not necessarily part of the ASF structure? Things that appeal to you in general?

Yeah, I mean, well, there are many reasons to engage in open source. I'll start with that. One of the things that I've always appreciated about open source in my career journey is the fact that it's kind of an altruistic resume builder. Like while you are contributing back to a community or a big project, you're also kind of building your own personal brand and your own experience around the industry. So that's one thing that's always been kind of a driver, not just for me, but also some of my students that I've taught about open source software.

The other thing, almost 100% of the time, it's been just scratching an itch, right? If you kind of go back to some of the original foundations of the earlier open source organizations out there, it was all about, hey, man, I just want to be able to change the software and satisfy my personal need.

So it's interesting, just the different types of projects that I've engaged in, even with simple drive-by patches or contributing to issues or something a little bit bigger, that was really just driven by, hey, I'm hacking on this thing at home, and I want to see how it works better by doing this, and then I contribute it upstream.
Yeah, well, exactly. When you think back to your early time in open source and in the ASF, can you think of people who acted as early influencers for you or mentors?
Yeah, absolutely.

A mutual friend of ours, of course, Rich Bowen, I've always had a tremendous amount of respect for him. He's a personal friend, as I would consider these days. It was, I don't know if I should tell this in a recorded session or not, he may get a big head about it, but when Rich Bowen commented, the guy who wrote the cookbook, wrote the HTTP server manual, commented on a change that I suggested, and he said, hey, this is

good, thanks. I was a little starstruck, it was kind of cool. So yeah, I mean, absolutely, Rich is a great example. Some of the folks on the Apache, the HTTP DMC at the time, were also intersections at work, so they kind of provided a little coaching and feedback there as well.

Yeah, well, and then you got to know Rich, and you kind of changed your mind maybe a little bit, but no, I'm just being mean. No, absolutely. I can see him being an excellent resource. When you, like, and you, so I know when I first met you, you haven't just done code contributions for the foundation. Can you talk a little bit of the other work that you've done?
I know you're taking a hiatus right now, but what are the other ways you like to participate in, yeah, ASL?

Yeah, so I've kind of run the gamut, I would guess, at the ASF. So it started as code contributions, but I liked the things that we do, I liked the mindset, so it always kind of drew me in and made me want to contribute more. It started as code contributions, and next thing you know, I'm presenting at conferences, which a starstruck moment was when I presented at my first Apache Con, and there was the president of the Apache Software Foundation, Rich Bowen, the guy that wrote the manual on Apache HTTPD, Nick Q, who wrote the module manual, Igor, and I mean, there were just a bunch of people there. I'm like, wow, these guys all came to see my present. This is amazing.

Anyhow, so that was maybe the second dose of the gateway drug, but yeah, participating in conferences, I became much more involved in the community, hanging out at the conference scene. So I was participating in the unconferences more and more each year, I started doing some adjacent work and hanging out in the ComDev PMC, which is the community development, how do we broaden this thing that we're doing, eventually became a member. I think within a year or so, there was a potential opening for vice president of fundraising, and I said, sure, I'll do it. Let's give it a shot.

I guess maybe a year or two after that, I was elected to the board of directors, served one term, because as you pointed out, we're kind of kicked up and it's pulled me a little bit away from the ASF, but anything from conferences to mentorship, to hanging out in PMCs, to the board, to fundraising, just kind of participating in a number of roles that I hope are valuable contributions to the foundation itself.

No. Well, I can say impartially, yes, they have been. So you really kind of outlined and you already answered one of my next questions about what impact the Apache Foundation has had on you. If you could sit back, in your opinion, what would be the impact that ASF has had on the rest of the open source ecosystem across the history of the foundation?

I would say without a doubt, the impact is immeasurable. I think even today, you can check me on this as the VP of marketing and publicity, I believe the ASF is still the largest software producing entity on the planet. And think about, I mean, just even wind it back, you know, 20 something years to when the foundation was formed, it kind of, what I described to my students is it kind of created a new, almost a new dialogue around open source.

You look at the GNU project and the, you know, the GPL, and there was almost like this radicalism kind of like, wow, those people are pretty crazy. But then you see this, this ASF entity come along in the late nineties, early 2000s. And it's kind of business centric, business focused.

It's not just about, you know, the radical software freedom idealism. And I think that, that has done so much for making open source the accepted way businesses do business today. I mean, you know, I actually recently told a colleague, I kind of feel like open source has won, now open governance, we're still kind of fighting that battle.

But I mean, if you go back into, you know, late nineties, early 2000s, open source was on the fringes, it was weird. And I think the Apache Software Foundation had a very big role in creating some momentum to get, for it to become like business friendly and business ready. And then of course, you know, just the myriad of projects, some that have come, some that have gone, you know, hundreds of projects, projects that have literally invented new industries, projects that have enhanced things, just, you know, in a measurable, immeasurable impact over time.
Yeah, absolutely. Everything you said is pretty much on the mark.

I believe, yes, we are still, as a nonprofit foundation, we are the world's largest open source foundation that's there in terms of pushing out software. So yeah, still true today. You alluded to this a little bit earlier in the conversation, but I want to kind of drill down a little bit because you were talking about like people getting involved in different ways. Like if you were talking to somebody who are just getting started in open source in general, not just the ASF, like what advice would you give to that person as far as what works and what doesn't work?

Yeah, I mean, I could spend a whole semester talking about that actually, which I have. So I've done some courses at University of Missouri St. Louis and Washington University here in St. Louis that's just about teaching open source. And it's almost like that question being answered in a whole curriculum, which is available on GitHub if you want to check it out or if anybody would like to check it out, full request welcome. You'll be able to take that and take it forward because that's still a gap.
We still have students that are graduating from university without really understanding what this open source stuff is. But that's the long way of answering your pointed question.

The pointed question, what I would advise them is figure out A, how you want to engage because you said it very well, an open source project is not just code. There's this entire community that needs to be thought about. If your talents are in graphic design, you can engage in an open source project without contributing code and do graphic design.

So think about how you would like to engage. And then the second follow on to that would be, figure out the community or the project that seems to fit your interests better. So for example, if I would like to engage in, let's say I have really good web design skills and I think this project over here is really cool, I would do a little recount on the project to see, are they open to new contributors? Are they welcoming? Is it really just one guy in his basement that's working on code and doesn't care if I open a pull request or is it this mega project like Kubernetes, which is open source, but man, you get lost in that swell really quickly.
So those two bits of advice, how do you want to engage and then make sure that where you choose to engage kind of works. And then lots in between.

Yeah, and I personally think it's wonderful that you're teaching a course on open source. We in my day job, we like to get involved with projects like that because it's so important for people to understand on, especially at the beginner level, what's going on because you're right. What you said earlier, open source basically is one, but it is still not commonly or completely understood what it's all about. There's still a lot of hiccups as far as understanding.

So the last question, this is something we've asked everybody and this is a very thought experiment one that we'd like to ask and based on your experience around open source and collaboration and all your professional life experience, let's just say that this video is going to be seen in a hundred years from now by one of your ancestors, your great grandson. So now you have a chance to like deliver some kind of wisdom to them. What would you say to your ancestor about anything as based on your life experiences so far?
That is a wild question.

I'm going to assume it's not necessarily related only to open source, but in the context of this conversation, I would actually want to spend a little time talking about the history and the world as it is today and the world as it was when I started engaging.

Because I imagine in a hundred years, people are going to look back at pretty much everything we do right now thinking, wow, that was so weird. And just kind of articulating the world that we're in, understanding where this future world that a hundred years from now ancestor is coming from, having some of that history I think would be, hopefully at least make me seem a little less antiquated and crazy when they view it.
Otherwise, Brian, I'm not even sure how to answer that question.

What would even be relevant today that's going to be relevant a hundred years from now is even a tough thing to wonder. Because less than a hundred years ago, we hadn't even taken to the skies a hundred years ago.

Right. Exactly. And my own children don't believe me when I say the internet wasn't a thing when I was younger. I mean, unless you worked for a defense contractor, you weren't really seeing the internet at all. And now it's so ubiquitous. The amount of change that's happened in my adult life alone is staggering. You know, I too can play the, yeah, when I was a kid, there were three channels on the TV game.
But I once played the sound of a 56K modem connecting for my son and he was terrified of the noises. He didn't know what was going on.

Yeah. It still triggers me, unfortunately. Yeah, and it will be interesting to see because it is a hopeful future for us that we are moving towards a more collaborative state, that collaboration is becoming more of the norm than the exception. And if that continues to be the case, I for one won't be around, but it would be neat to know how that kind of all works out.
So, yeah, well, Daniel, thank you so much for your time and coming in and sharing with us some of your insights about open source and the ASF.
Yeah, absolutely, Brian. Thanks for having me. And it's always a pleasure to connect with you.
Okay. Thank you all for watching this new interview.
Look forward to more conversations around open source and its history in the days to come. Thank you so much and have a great day.
